Critically, this conflict impairs performance in partial repetition trials relative to complete repetition and complete alternation trials, resulting in “partial repetition costs” (Fig. 2).

We programmed the experiment in PsychoPy (Peirce et al., 2019), converted it to an online format on Pavlovia (https://pavlovia.org/), and presented it to participants via a web browser outside of the lab.Experimental design
Each trial included six successive stimuli (Fig. 1).
First, as expected, there was an interaction between color and response, F(1, 39) = 114.329, p < 0.001, (Fig. 3a).
Error bars indicate ± 1 SEM as calculated in JASPSecond, as expected, there was an interaction between location and response, F(1, 39) = 8.209, p < 0.007, (Fig. 3b).
First, as in the mean RT data, there was an interaction between color and response, F(1, 39) = 76.11, p < 0.001, (Fig. 3c).
Second, and also as in the mean RT data, there was an interaction between location and response, F(1, 39) = 26.45, p < 0.001, (Fig. 3d).
First, as in Experiment 1, there was an interaction between color and response, F(1, 65) = 22.16, p < 0.001, (Fig. 4a).
Error bars indicate ± 1 SEM as calculated in JASPSecond, as in Experiment 1, there was an interaction between location and response, F(1, 65) = 7.09, p = 0.01, (Fig. 4b).
First, as in the mean RT data, we observed an interaction between color and response, F(1, 65) = 23.11, p < 0.001, (Fig. 4c).
Second, as in the mean RT data, there was an interaction between location and response, F(1, 65) = 6.57, p = 0.013, (Fig. 4d).
Consequently, Fig. 5 in the next section presents only the partial repetition costs that appeared in the mean z-RT data.

This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between color and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5a and c).

Follow-up analyses revealed that the complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5c is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5a).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to color was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5c has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5a).
In the mean z-RT data, for example, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.

We speculate that less signaling of the incorrect response in partial repetition trials wherein the color alternated and the response repeated reduced this index of the complete repetition advantage in the four-choice PRC task.Effects related to the interaction among experiment, location, and response
Consistent with the binding plus signaling hypothesis, we observed a significant interaction among experiment, location, and response (mean z-RT: F(1, 104) = 4.60, p = 0.034,; mean ER: F(1, 104) = 10.86, p = 0.001,).This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between location and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5b and d).

Follow-up analyses revealed that our measure of the “signal-free” complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5d is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5b).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to location was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5d has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5b).
For example, in the mean z-RT data, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Each trial of this task consists of three successive events (Fig. 1).
Critically, this conflict impairs performance in partial repetition trials relative to complete repetition and complete alternation trials, resulting in “partial repetition costs” (Fig. 2).

This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between color and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5a and c).

Follow-up analyses revealed that the complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5c is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5a).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to color was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5c has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5a).
In the mean z-RT data, for example, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.

We speculate that less signaling of the incorrect response in partial repetition trials wherein the color alternated and the response repeated reduced this index of the complete repetition advantage in the four-choice PRC task.Effects related to the interaction among experiment, location, and response
Consistent with the binding plus signaling hypothesis, we observed a significant interaction among experiment, location, and response (mean z-RT: F(1, 104) = 4.60, p = 0.034,; mean ER: F(1, 104) = 10.86, p = 0.001,).This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between location and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5b and d).

Follow-up analyses revealed that our measure of the “signal-free” complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5d is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5b).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to location was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5d has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5b).
For example, in the mean z-RT data, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.

This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between color and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5a and c).

Follow-up analyses revealed that the complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5c is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5a).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to color was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5c has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5a).
In the mean z-RT data, for example, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5a and c.

We speculate that less signaling of the incorrect response in partial repetition trials wherein the color alternated and the response repeated reduced this index of the complete repetition advantage in the four-choice PRC task.Effects related to the interaction among experiment, location, and response
Consistent with the binding plus signaling hypothesis, we observed a significant interaction among experiment, location, and response (mean z-RT: F(1, 104) = 4.60, p = 0.034,; mean ER: F(1, 104) = 10.86, p = 0.001,).This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between location and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5b and d).

Follow-up analyses revealed that our measure of the “signal-free” complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5d is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5b).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to location was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5d has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5b).
For example, in the mean z-RT data, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Consequently, Fig. 5 in the next section presents only the partial repetition costs that appeared in the mean z-RT data.

Effects related to the interaction among experiment, location, and response
Consistent with the binding plus signaling hypothesis, we observed a significant interaction among experiment, location, and response (mean z-RT: F(1, 104) = 4.60, p = 0.034,; mean ER: F(1, 104) = 10.86, p = 0.001,).This three-way interaction occurred because the interaction between location and response was smaller in the four-choice PRC task than in the two-choice PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, see Fig. 5b and d).

Follow-up analyses revealed that our measure of the “signal-free” complete alternation advantage was smaller in the four-choice PRC task, which controlled for signaling, than in the standard two-choice PRC task (e.g., the difference between the two points on the right side of Fig. 5d is smaller than the corresponding difference in Fig. 5b).

Our second index of the complete alternation advantage related to location was also smaller in the four-choice (vs. two-choice) PRC task (e.g., for the mean z-RT data, the solid line in Fig. 5d has a shallower slope than the solid line in Fig. 5b).
For example, in the mean z-RT data, the difference between the lower left and upper left points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
Specifically, the difference between the lower left and upper right points does not differ in Fig. 5b and d.
